title: How to Create a Faux Finish With a Rag

steps.headline: Prepare your area for painting by cleaning the walls, filling in cracks and nail holes, sanding, applying masking tape, etc.
Apply a base coat to the surface with a satin sheen paint or BIN primer.
Allow the base coat to dry.
Dampen your blotting rag(s) by washing or soaking them thoroughly and then wringing them nearly dry.
steps.description: Soft cotton rags work well, as do old tee-shirts.

steps.headline: Mix your paint with the glaze according to instructions on the can of Glaze.
steps.description: The common ratio is 4 parts glaze to one part paint.

steps.headline: Roll the paint/glaze on the wall in 4' x 4' sections with a short nap roller.
Use your dampened cloth to blot off the paint/glaze with a soft cotton rag in a dabbing and patting motion.
steps.description: An interesting effect can be obtained by twisting the rag into a long roll and then rolling that twisted rag up the wall in a line.

steps.headline: Continue working your along the wall in 4' x 4' sections: rolling the paint/glaze on and dabbing it off until the whole wall is completed.
Allow each layer to dry completely before applying the next.

Allow the base coat to dry.  Dampen your blotting rag(s) by washing or soaking them thoroughly and then wringing them nearly dry. Soft cotton rags work well, as do old tee-shirts. Mix your paint with the glaze according to instructions on the can of Glaze. The common ratio is 4 parts glaze to one part paint. Roll the paint/glaze on the wall in 4' x 4' sections with a short nap roller.  Use your dampened cloth to blot off the paint/glaze with a soft cotton rag in a dabbing and patting motion. An interesting effect can be obtained by twisting the rag into a long roll and then rolling that twisted rag up the wall in a line. Continue working your along the wall in 4' x 4' sections: rolling the paint/glaze on and dabbing it off until the whole wall is completed.  Allow each layer to dry completely before applying the next.
